segments.text: Okay, so you were...
So we were in the Admiralty Islands, and the 1st Cavalry had just recently cleaned it up.
We had a large naval base there.
And from there we prepared one of our companies, Company B, I believe, to carry the 1st Cavalry in.
So you were preparing then to go into Leyte?
Right.
The invasion of the Philippines.
Right, we got them ready.
And you were basically under Douglas MacArthur then?
Yes, we were a separate battalion, an orphan.
Really, we were under General Kruger, Sixth Army.
So we then, from there, the rest of the battalion shipped to Atape, New Guinea.
And see, each division had an amphibious kit, which was composed of a few amphibious tractors.
And then the rest of the battalion took over those amphibious kits in the 43rd Division.
which was National Guard Division from Maine to Vermont.
And we trained their people and ours for invasion, and they got in government.
Was that invasion the first action that you saw, or were you still trained?
It was the first formal action.
I'd seen informal action.
What do you mean, that bomb?
Well, there was a few stray Japs still.
You don't kill them all at one time and stuff like that, but it was very minor stuff.
And then we carried the...
So you were in on the L.A.T.
Gulf?
No, I was not in on the L.A.T.
Gulf.
This one company was.
The rest of the battalion carried the 43rd Division in on the Lingayen Gulf.
which was a larger operation.
We carried the 4030 and I was naval liaison for that.
So were you on a ship then offshore?
Yes, the regimental commander of the attacking regiment and myself about 2 30 in the morning went aboard a subchaser and by then this
LCI, landing craft infantry.
Are you familiar with those?
Small ships.
But they mounted rockets on decks.
And he and I went into 1500 yards and marked the line of departure.
We were in the LCVP.
And then the rocket ships came in and fired their rockets.
And then we marked the line of departure for the amphibious tractor waves, which there were just several battalions of amphibious tractors, all those troops coming in.
And as soon as the second wave passed, then he and I went ashore.
And then I immediately started to dash across the beach and immediately started pulling people together.
You break down in small units, and you try to get them back up.
See, by then, the Japanese had begun to pull back and let you land, and then try to knock you off the beach.
And that's basically what they tried to do there.
In some areas.
As we compared in later notes, and I prefer this to be off the record, when the first Cavs got out of their vehicles, they just got in like hunters and started out.
43rd got out.
It took about 30 minutes to get them up off the ground.
But some of them see our way.
I'm not sure.
Training perhaps.
But anyway, they misused some of our M50s tractors because they're primarily beach vehicles.
They have
maybe half an inch of armor across the front.
Not very much.
They carried some of them down the road acting as tanks.
We had a .35 caliber machine gun each one.
And they got some boresighted holes from 37 millimeter Jap guns and stuck others in rice paddies and stuff like that.
Not in every case, but.
And as the XO, down as the XO, were you in a command post then?
Yes.
Or were you off in the field?
You were right behind the lines, probably.
At that time, I was hiding behind a sand dune and trying to get control, because we had very little control until things began to move in, because we had several waves of people running in.
And I was neither afraid, scared, excited, or nervous.
All of them rolled up into one.
You can condition a man's mind.
So in other words, you felt that the training was very beneficial.
Oh, definitely.
And an interesting thing, there wasn't a,
See, there was been a heavy preliminary bombardment by the Navy.
I don't believe there was a square foot of beach if there wasn't some shell breakage.
Although I'm sure they did very little damage to the Japanese who had pulled back.
But the Kamikaze is popular.
Tell me about Kamikaze.
Well, we had some 500 ships that we got in harbor.
And one of them, unfortunately, buried himself in the hold of a freighter, which carried our beer and ration.
So did the freighter sink?
I assume it did.
But I think it was a Black Widow, I believe it was a P-61 Black Widow, almost like a P-51 night fighter.
It came over from the ocean.
And none of us had ever been indoctrinated with a Black Widow.
And the whole fleet opened up, freighters and all, and there was all kind of flak falling on us.
We were crawling under coconut logs.
And just as he got to the horizon, he got a fuselage burst.
And he went.
And of course, we were harassed by
Japanese fighters, not necessarily kamikazes.
Did the Japanese have any artillery to shoot at that time?
Yes, they had captured an 11-inch crack mounted gun, and they had it around the bay up in the mountain.
And we referred to him as Piscol Charlie, because about 11 o'clock at night, they'd run it out.
The adjutant and I had a foxhole that was about four feet square with sandbags around, real comfortable.
In an Amtrak, you can carry an awful lot of equipment, including a cot and sponsors.
So we had rather developed foxholes.
And we'd stand there in our underwear and boots and helmet.
And around the bay, we could see a flash.
And we could count 21 seconds and duck down, and we'd get simultaneously the sound of the muzzle burst, the whine, and the explosion.
One, two, three.
And
And I'd say, Bill, how far away do you think that was?
About a mile?
Well, I'm afraid it's closer than that.
I said, half a mile?
I'm afraid it's closer than that.
All right, 300 yards.
Yeah.
How'd they knock that gun off?
My classmate and very close friend by the name of Taylor, who was a company commander in the first camp,
See, the first cab finally came on in.
And we were visiting after the war up here, and he turned around.
I tell him about the piss call.
Charlie turned around his wife, Topsy, and said, you hear what the man's saying?
See, we had a battalion of 155 guns.
Every time he'd fire, they'd fire a battalion salvo.
But a gun is too flat a detector.
And Taylor said, you hear what the man's saying?
That I and my company had to take him by hand.
So that's how they got him?
They had to send the company up there?
That was the first cab.
Of course, there was a lot of Aggies in the first cab.
Yeah.
See, it was a square regiment still, even though we'd gone to Triangle Division.
I mean, Square Division.
Even though we'd gone to Triangle Division.
Which I don't know whether that means anything to you or not.
No.
Well, before World War II, all our divisions were square.
That was...
four battalions each.
And then they found out that the Triangle Division, which was three battalions each, was more flexible.
Except in the armor, which all of the modern divisions have gone to, in the armor, to start out with, we had Combat Command A, Combat Command B, and the Reserve Command.
And all they consisted of was the headquarters and headquarters companies.
And then they had so many tank battalions, so many infantry battalions, and they attached to them the combat command for each individual operation they tailored them.
Because if it were a heavily wooded country, not particularly suitable for tanks who were heavy on infantry,
And the rest of the Army adopted it after the war.
But prior to the war, I mean, during the war, they were trying to division.
The troops were not attached to that regiment.
They were a part of it, you see.
Did you have any Filipinos with you, fighting alongside you?
Not initially.
But then it became our job to train the Philippine guerrillas.
Poor job.
Tough job.
Can you describe it?
Well, among other things, there were pockets of Japanese, including Japanese Marines.
Unusual for a Japanese race when you had to be six feet tall to be a Marine.
So we trained guerrillas the best we could to clean out those pockets.
And they were strange people.
One night, we were loading up some to go out.
And as he got in the truck, he handed them a rifle.
But this one said, but, sir, I did not join the Army to fight.
I joined the Army to play in the land.
They could be tough in certain situations, but they were not that well trained as a whole.
It takes a long time to train that long.
And they'd issue rice rations.
They'd walk 10 miles back and say, the bowl's cracked.
They just weren't very well trained.
That was one of the major problems.
Well, that was a problem.
I'd say their temperament and so forth.
They're not the world's greatest fighters in organized combat.
Individuals, they might be.
So we trained guerrillas to clean out those pockets, and I think finally cleaned most of them out.
And they did or we did?
Who cleaned most of them out?
Both of us.
They cleaned out a few.
We cleaned out most of them.
See, part of the thing had to swing up toward Baguio, if you ever heard of Baguio or not, but that was beautiful in the mountains.
Not too long after that, I left the unit and went up as assistant G4, 1st Corps Headquarters.
So I wasn't doing much fighting things.
an awful lot of hard work.
Now when was that?
I don't know the date.
Is this when you were promoted to major?
No, I was promoted to major in 1942.
Okay, so was this Well, I was already Okay, so you were a major at this time.
Yeah.
And I went up to System G4 by Corps.
And we had a full colonel by the name of Tommy Sawyer.
He was G4.
He had been quartermaster.
And when he became G4, there was a short, fat, 27-year-old captain
from Texas A&M assistant corps quartermaster.
The best they could do in promoting a major, he was a whiz.
He was a whiz.
I can't remember the name now.
But he was sharp.
You don't become assistant corps quartermaster unless you're sharp.
I don't know if you're familiar with what a corps is, but it's strictly a tactical avenue.
We don't have any supply functions.
Divisions have it.
Army has it.
But not corps.
We're tactical.
But I guess I was assistant G4 in charge of transportation and shipping.
And I worked up there.
See, then we would start planning the invasion of the Philippines.
Were you in Manila at this time?
Was that the headquarters?
No, I was down in Rosales.
I'd been to Manila.
It was my sister outfit.
I fought all the way through the whole thing.
And did you start some of the planning?
We had an operation called Operation Blacklist, which was the invasion of Japan.
The main island is Cayuse, and this was a smaller island, Huntsville.
And our plan was, it was cut by a river across it.
The plan was two divisions here, one division here, a division in the regimental combat team in the floating reserve.
What my job was as assistant G4, in the past, as divisions landed, they set up their dumps on the beach, ammunition dumps, quartermaster dumps, and so on and so forth.
And then when they got too far inland and the Army came in, and the Army took them over, not Corps.
That wasn't our function.
And then the Army would not like exactly where they were, so it would be a big moving around this, moving around that.

So my job in that was to, using aerial photographs, was to coordinate with Army above and divisions below so that we could mutually agree on the initial location of those dumps so Army could build on them without having to move.
And then we were also getting our troop assignments.
And I'd complain to Army G-4.
I said, man, you switch these things around.
He said, what are you complaining about?
He said, we've already handled eight of them before we ever signed you one.
Because they'd signed the 355th Engineer Firefighting Detachment.
Two days later, it was transferred somewhere else.
And then, an interesting thing, General N.S.P.
Bull Swift was our corps commander and had come from the 1st Cav.
earlier.
And some Air Corps generals were trying to bet him $1,500,000 to warrant me over.
And see, I was working from 8.30 in the morning until noon, and went and took a nap.
And went to work about 2 and worked until about 5, and had a drink and supper, and then come back and worked about 7 or 3.30 in the morning, seven days a week.
And they were trying to bet that money that the war bill was, they knew about the atomic bomb, we didn't.
And then suddenly VJ Day came.
And that was about 5 o'clock in the afternoon when I found out about it.
So I went to the officer's bunk and had a couple of drinks and then came back to work from invading Japan to the occupation of Japan.
Then they split I-Corps into two groups, I-Corps Forward and I-Corps Rear.
And they left Brigadier General James F. Collins, who was the Corps Artillery Commander, as Commander General High Court Rear, and left me back as G4 High Court Rear.
And I have never worked with a minor person in my life.
He was my ideal of a West Pointer.
About six feet, two inches tall, handsome, slender, blue eyed, deep voice.
And one of the finest persons I've ever worked with in my life.
Anything I wanted, I was the one to see.
Operations weren't doing anything.
First place, I had to ship troops to Japan.
I ended up shipping 85,000 troops to Japan.
And all of the problems.
First place, we had two ports, Nagoya and another port.
And I had to decide which one going in there and which one going in there.
I had to depend on the Navy for bottoms to ship them in, APAs, AKAs, LCTs, LSTs.
had to supervise all the landing operations.
We had 22 beach points.
Down on the beach, we had an engineer at Bolton Shore, West Point, a colonel in charge of it.
And I went down there to him, and I said, Colonel, I'm the G4 I Corps Rear.
I don't know what the hell I'm doing.
I need some help.
He said, what do you need?
I said, well, could I get a road down here?
He said, damn right.
I said, Major, put him a road just like he wants.
And I said, we're going to be doing 24-hour operations.
Is it possible to get some lighting?
He said, yeah.
I told another guy, whatever I want to do.

because i went down and told him i needed help and we loaded sometimes 24 hours a day sometimes not 24 hours a day it depended for how many months i'd guess 45 days see our we had these beach ones that lsts could come up
We had to lighter things out to APA and AKAs.
I don't know if you know the APA and the AKAs, the LSTs, but we always had some of these beach points knocked out because of sand building up.
Sometimes we had two high tides today, so we'd bring in a ship on a high tide and take them back out on the next up tide.
And we could do two, sometimes during periods, and sometimes only one, depending on tides.
So we were pretty well 24-hour operation.
But see, you'd plan all these things.
I had a quarter-master loading transport team.
And Lieutenant Colonel in charge, he was senior to me.
This gives you an idea of General Collins.
because I had laid out all the troop areas and so forth.
Then I found out that these troops were coming to the beach with no means of feeding themselves.
So I had to go back to that in their boat and shore regiment colonel and ask him for help in setting up the kitchen.
We were feeding 1,000, 1,500 people a week.
And I took John Collins down there one day, a long, tall, lanky nigger with his hat on sideways, a big Adam's apple.
He was a mess guard.
And I said, what's that dump out there right back there?
He said, sir, I can't get garbage, something to drain down there.
I had them build it up this way.
He showed us over it.
He showed us his.
where he kept his ration.
You know, Filipinos are going to eat this.
This is guarded 24 hours a day.
General liked it, and so he died, because that guy knew what he was doing.
But see, these two ports in Japan, nobody told me that one of them was closed because of mines.
All of them were going to one place.
So you thought you were shipping the troops to two different places, but actually you're only shipping them to one.
And I couldn't depend on my plans on APA or AKS because, you know, the final authority is the captain of that ship.
He may decide that his ship's not seaworthy and put a deck.
Hi, Mama.
I want you to meet Dr. Anderson.
This is my wife, Jo.
Nice to meet you.
But he might decide that his ship's not seaworthy, and he had a great big hold I was going to put trucks in.
He might weld a bulkhead right down the middle, and I could put jeeps in.
So this quartermaster loading transport team would go aboard and check.
And I was walking by one night, and a gentleman called and said, come here.
I said, what?
And he said, there's been a lot of misinformation about what was out here.
He said, I want it stopped.
He said, you want to tell that Lieutenant Colonel or you want me to?
I said, I'll be glad to tell him.
The only thing is, tell me who's running it.
He said, by God, you are.
He worked for a guy like that.
When did you first get to Japan?
When they sent you over there?
On the last ship.
September, I think.
What were the conditions like?
In Japan?
Yeah.
Well, defeated country.
I was stationed in Osaka.
Osaka.
And firebombed almost left me.
Not all of it, but a great portion of it, known as Pittsburgh.
I'd like to go back to the Philippines for a minute.
Part of my orders were that each soldier would be equipped with a farm-fitting bedroll.
And I had the 6th Division sitting down here by a beach.
by some loaded dogs, and I went up to the general, and I said, General, if we get them shipped out all set, the dog could sure would help us.
He said, call a meeting up there with them.
I said, yes, sir.
On the way up, he said, you tell them what you want.
I said, I'm a general.
They'll look at me out of this thing and shake my head like that.
So we made a ring, shipped them across the dock, and got rid of them.
And then 10 days later, they transferred them out of our command to somebody else's command.
But I had to furnish everybody one of those farm-fitting things.
So I had borne 10,000 from this division, getting 5,000 from Manila.
Nobody neglected to tell me that when they got to Japan, they were taken away from them.
Because that clothes-fitting thing was causing upper respiratory infection.
Nobody ever told me that.
The other thing.
All my female personnel, which were nurses and a few Red Crossers, the only way I could carry them to the beach was in the ambulance.
So nobody could see.
Rape was going on when the other right hand left.
And I had a group of them.
I was going to ship on an APA personnel.
Quartermaster Lowry.
Was it Filipinos then, or were rapes Americans, or Americans, or everybody?
Blacks.
blacks.
In fact, in the south of the city, the only way you could take out a female personnel on a date was two couples and both of the males would be on it.
They hung nine minutes of play.
I'd rather not have that.
They assault and rape the nurse and kill the male escort.
And then did they have a court-martial?
I wasn't in New Guinea at the time.
Anyway, that's why the order came down.
But then my quartermaster's little transport team came by, told me there was only one set of heads on that APA.
Well, you can't have female personnel using the same set of heads.
So I called 6th Army in Manila.
I said, how about shipping them by air?
And he said, well, I'll tell you what I'll do.
belong to hospital nurses, which had come in from Marseille, France, incidentally.
He said, I've got some extra nurses in Japan.
He said, I'll transfer these out, and when they get there, I'll transfer some more in.
I said, boy, you've got to deal.
We weren't very close to that stuff.
Those were the kind of problems.
I had a telephone by my bed all night, and it rang a lot of times.
But General Collins, he'd come over and he'd say, come on, let's go down and eat.
He'd say, oh, General so-and-so, he's a Jew, but he sure slacks ham.
He'd say, well, go down and eat with him.
And boy, he was a fine guy to work with.
And he got me out of trouble in Japan.
I was out.
I had an Aggie muster.
And I had it in the hotel.
A couple of Aggies got out in front of me.
I had a flat on their Jeep.
They were pretty drunk.
They were cussing.
Raising a pail coming right up.
Pilling swifts on the road.
So next morning my chief of section, Tommy Sawyer, said, don't worry, chief of staff won't see you until 8.30.
And I said, what about it?
He said, last night.
He said, now just go in and keep your mouth shut.
He said, if he restricts you to quarters for 30 days or something, I'll go to bat for you.
I said, restrict me to quarters?
I'm supposed to go home in two weeks.
He said, you may not.
So I went in to General Murray, and he said, your boys raised hell last night.
Yes, sir.
The general told me to do something about it.
Yes, sir.
He said, next time, take them out the back door.
Yes, sir.
I went back, Tommy saw you, and I said, everything's okay.
He said, you can thank General Collins for that.
He came up at breakfast.
He told Murray to do something about it.
The colleagues had him by the arm.
What happened to Collins?
He became a commanding general for Pacific Command.
I don't know whether he's in the book or not.
Have you ever seen the book?
Mama, where's my book?
I get this every year, a roster of retired Army general officers.
And then in the front, they ice against it.
Well, I don't know where it is.
I think it's down here, too.
They're kind enough to put in the list of the active officers by how they rank.
It's always interesting to hear it, to me.
General of the Army.
Brad Lamb.
Well, he's a general of the Army that retires.
But see, they list them on their rank.
And then this is a retired guy.
Let's see what Collins is.
He became a director of the American Red Cross at one time.
Here he is, James F. He lives at 4133 North River Street, Arlington, Virginia.
What I used to like when he was a brigadier, we'd be riding this old Aussie Army sedan with no rear shocks on it, bouncing along.
pull out his paycheck.
He said, sure it's going to be tough when he busts me back to a major after the war.
Was there a lot of fear that people would lose a lot of grade as soon as the war was over?
All the brigadiers went back.
See, during World War II, Terry
Every promotion was AUS, Army of the United States, which was temporary.
Yeah, temporary promotion.
Right.
Now, the brigadiers went back.
In fact, one that had been a brigadier became a commandant out of the A&M.
He's a good friend of mine.
He's a colonel.
Most of them got back to the general officer.
See, in this, in right here, in this book here, there are diamonds.
And those plus there, which... What does that stand for?
It stands for A-B-S. And here's F-D-N-E.
Just to get an idea of how many generals they have in the Army.
Yeah, and who they are.
Get an idea of what their relative rank is.
So it's interesting to look through it.
I see people I've served with in various capacities.
But anyway, in Japan, my primary job there, I got there, was the Corps had been modified so many times that it was
Amendment Slank 21-6 to Amendment 10, where it got down to a poor company commander could never tell what was latest information.
So that was one of my principal jobs was to completely revise it and bring it up to date, which I did and then carried up to Army for approval, and they said, well,
just follows ours, and I said, that's what it's supposed to do.
Our order's supposed to be based on ours.
And, of course, it got wise on certain things.
Some of the troops or divisions would call in and say they have seized the submarine dock.
What'd I do with it?
I'd call Army.
They'd say, seize, hold, and guard pending further notifications.
So I quit calling them.
I just tell our group the same thing.
And it took me two or two and a half months hard work.
When did you leave your parents?
Approximately December 1, 1946.
45, yes.
Sorry about that.
Did you have any relations with the Japanese people at all?
Oh, not much.
A little bit.
How'd they behave?
Hmm?
How'd they behave?
Oh, fine.
Our quarters were in the
new Osaka Hotel, which was a seven-story hotel modeled on one in Cleveland that was in Osaka.
And we had it pretty deluxe.
They had taken out steam heaters and wore them, but they put them back.
And we had a house ball on every floor.
People would come in and turn your bed down at night.
And we had a, see, they broke people.
See, a major is a field officer, but they broke it down in the Corps as colonel and above and other officers.
So I ate with the peons down on the ring.
Lobby had a printed menu.
It was beautiful.
Of course, it was GI food or GI-traded potatoes.
It sure sounded good.
Then they had a mezzanine dining room for you to take visitors.
And on the fifth floor, we had a big, huge bar.
It was luxurious quarters there.
So you were treated really well?
Yeah.
The army just complicated it.
Sure, right.
Were you eager to get home in December of 45?
Was I eager to get home?
Did you ever consider staying in?
At one time, they had a deal that you could go regular army as second lieutenant.
Oh, really?
This was after the war?
No, it was during the war.
You could go regular army as a second lieutenant?
I mean, they would promote you up, you know.
He might forget about you by the first lieutenant or something.
He'll be starting all over again.
And I was tired.
I had worked hard and seen enough killing.
I'll guarantee you I didn't want to go on an invasion of Japan lately.
Tommy Sawyer told me,
Come on, Japan, and stay another year.
I said, I'll promote you to a lieutenant colonel.
And I said, Colonel, if it delays me by so much as one day, I'm not interested.
I was tired and nervous.
I'd be fought.
In those areas, your life's on the line all the time.
I slept with a pistol in my pillow at night.
I've been shot at and bombed at.
Even as late as 50, I built a house out in North Oakwood.
And I'd walk outside and say, gosh, what a beautiful night.
And then suddenly the cockaneers see if I can hear a plane coming.
And we had a little breakfast with a window in it.
Absolutely would not have seen that in the night with the light on without the blinds on.
Just, your neck crawls.
One of those picks to take a pot shot at you.
It's, uh, and my service was a whole lot less rough than a lot of others.
So you were eager to get back to the civilian life, huh?
I was eager to get back to the States.
At that time I was tired and worn out and
We had people been over there three years, and they were just walking ghosts.
The conditions, the adamant that you took from malaria and all of that, boy, just, they're hard.
Were you going to get back in the automobile business?
Were those your plans?
Yeah.
Well, see, I had to be.
Yeah.
My dad ran during the war.
Of course, couldn't get any cars.
We just let him take it over.
My partner worked for the quartermaster out at the base.
We let my dad take it over, and just whatever he made on repairs and parking, he kept.
He owned the building.
He paid himself rent.
But I was tired.
I was tired of, you know, being in a position to think.
